questions.text:
A 66 year old lady had a history of falling at home and injuring her left wrist before 1 year. She did not seek any treatment then. Now she presents with following deformity. Identify the correct statements regarding the condition.

1. Dinner fork deformity
2. Garden spade deformity
3. Malunited extra-articular distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement
4. Malunited extra-articular distal radius fracture with volar displacement
questions.solution:
1. Dinner fork deformity
  2. Malunited extra-articular distal radius fracture with dorsal displacement

Dinner fork deformity in Colle's fracture

PATHOANATOMY

Displacement:
The fracture line runs transversely at the cortico-cancellous junction. In the majority of cases, one or more of the displacements described below occur; however, a few cases may present as a crack fracture without displacement.

Displacements seen in Colles' fracture:

  • Impaction of fragments
  • Dorsal displacement
  • Dorsal tilt
  • Lateral displacement
  • Lateral tilt
  • Supination

As displacement occurs, there may be some comminution of the dorsal and lateral cortices, as well as the soft cancellous bone of the distal fragment. Rarely, the entire distal fragment may be fragmented into multiple pieces.

Commonly Associated Injuries with Colles' Fracture:

  • Fracture of the styloid process of the ulna
  • Rupture of the ulnar collateral ligament
  • Rupture of the triangular cartilage of the ulna
  • Rupture of the interosseous radio-ulnar ligament, resulting in radio-ulnar subluxation

Colles' Fracture Healing and Malunion

A Colles' fracture generally unites, but malunion is common in a significant proportion of cases. The primary cause of malunion is the redisplacement of the fracture within the plaster cast, leading to a characteristic "dinner fork" deformity.

Consequences of Malunion:

  • Limitation of wrist movement
  • Restricted forearm rotation

Statements 2,4: Garden spade deformity is seen in malunited Smith's fracture which is extra-articular distal radius fracture with volar displacement.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 112, 114.

questions.text: Identify the spot where nerve supplying the deltoid muscle can possibly get injured
questions.solution:
AXILLARY NERVE


Anatomy: The axillary nerve originates from the posterior cord of the brachial plexus and curves backward along the lower border of the subscapularis muscle. It crosses the quadrangular space and positions itself on the medial side of the surgical neck of the humerus, lying medial and inferior to the shoulder joint capsule.

Branches:

  • Anterior Branch:
    Continues horizontally between the deltoid muscle and the surgical neck of the humerus, supplying the remainder of the deltoid muscle.
  • Posterior Branch:
    Supplies the teres minor and the posterior part of the deltoid muscle. It terminates as a cutaneous nerve, providing sensation to the skin over the lower half of the deltoid.

Option B - Radial nerve along the radial groove commonly gets injured in humeral shaft fractures.

Option D - Ulnar nerve passes near to the medial epicondyle and gets injured during surgery of condylar fractures or due to injury.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 68.

questions.text: Choose the correct option stating the attitude of the lower limb in a patient with x-ray as shown below.
questions.solution:
POSTERIOR DISLOCATION OF THE HIP

Overview: In posterior dislocation of the hip, the head of the femur is pushed out of the acetabulum towards the back. In approximately 50% of cases, this is accompanied by a chip fracture of the posterior lip of the acetabulum, in which case it is termed a fracture-dislocation.

MECHANISM OF INJURY

The injury occurs due to a force directed along the shaft of the femur while the hip is flexed. A moderately severe force is necessary to dislocate the hip, commonly seen in motor vehicle accidents. In such scenarios, the occupant is thrown forward, and their knee strikes the dashboard. The force is then transmitted up the femoral shaft, resulting in posterior dislocation of the hip. This mechanism is often referred to as a "dashboard injury."

DIAGNOSIS

Clinical Features: An isolated posterior dislocation of the hip can be diagnosed with relative ease. Key signs include:

  • History of Severe Trauma: The patient typically reports significant trauma leading to the injury.
  • Symptoms: Pain, swelling, and deformity (characterized by flexion, adduction, and internal rotation of the leg).
  • Leg Shortening: The affected leg may appear shorter than the opposite leg.
  • Palpation: The head of the femur may be palpable in the gluteal region.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 130.

questions.text: Identify the injury and choose correct option
questions.solution:
Monteggia Fracture-Dislocation

Overview

  • Fracture of the upper third of the ulna with dislocation of the radial head.
  • Caused by a fall on an outstretched hand or direct trauma to the upper forearm.

Types

  1. Extension Type (Common): Ulna fracture angulates anteriorly; radial head dislocates anteriorly.
  2. Flexion Type: Ulna fracture angulates posteriorly; radial head dislocates posteriorly.

Diagnosis

  • In any upper ulna fracture, check for radial head dislocation (confirmed via X-ray).

Treatment

  • Initial: Reduction under general anesthesia. Monitor with weekly X-rays for 3-4 weeks.
  • If unsuccessful: Open reduction and internal fixation (ORIF) with a plate.

Complications

  • Malunion: Common in conservative treatment, leading to forearm deformity and limited movement.

Option B - This injury is the counterpart of the Monteggia fracture-dislocation. Here, there is a fracture of the lower third of the radius with dislocation or subluxation of the distal radio-ulnar joint.

Option D - Terrible triad - Radial head fracture + Elbow dislocation (Ligament tear) + Coronoid fracture

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 110.

questions.text: A 54yr old male presented with severe pain and deformity of right hip. Xray showed severe arthritis of right hip and hence he was advised total hip replacement. During the surgery the femoral head cartilage was found as follows. Probable medical condition this patient may be having:
questions.solution:
Alkaptonuric Arthritis (Ochronosis)

Overview

  • Cause: Inherited defect in the metabolism of phenylalanine and tyrosine.
  • Results in the excretion of homogentisic acid in urine.
  • Long-term accumulation of homogentisic acid in cartilage and connective tissues leads to black/brown discoloration.

Clinical Features

  • Onset: Joint symptoms typically appear after age 40.
  • Commonly Affected Joints: Spine and shoulder joints.
  • Additional Signs:
    • Pigment deposits in the sclera.
    • Dark brown urine upon standing (due to oxidation of homogentisic acid).

X-Ray Findings

  • Disc space calcification.
  • Peri-articular calcification in large joints.

Treatment

  • Similar to the management of osteoarthritis.

Option B and C-


Option D - Ankylosing spondylitis usually affects the SI joints and spine. Bamboo spine appearance on x-ray is characteristic.

Reference. J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number. 294

questions.text: Most common cause of pain at the point marked '4' in the image below:
questions.solution:
Option A,B and D


Retrocalcaneal Bursitis/Haglund Deformity

Overview

  • Inflammation of the retrocalcaneal bursa, often associated with insertional Achilles tendinopathy and the presence of a Haglund deformity.

Symptoms

  • Deep posterior heel pain.
  • Fullness and tenderness on palpation medial and lateral to the Achilles tendon.
  • Pain increases with ankle dorsiflexion.
  • Commonly occurs alongside insertional Achilles tendinopathy.

Diagnosis

  • Clinical examination shows tenderness and swelling at the back of the heel.
  • Lateral foot X-rays reveal the presence of a Haglund deformity.
  • MRI is rarely necessary for diagnosis.

Nonoperative Treatment

  • NSAIDs, external padding, ice, and heel-lift orthotics for pain relief and support.
  • Shoewear modification to reduce pressure on the heel.
  • Steroid injections are avoided due to the risk of Achilles tendon rupture.

Operative Treatment

  • Débridement of the inflamed retrocalcaneal bursa.
  • Excision of Haglund deformity, if present, to relieve symptoms.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page number. 1275

questions.text: Identify the test being performed in the image below that is used in clinical examination of shoulder joint.
questions.solution:
Lift-Off Test

Overview

  • Described by Gerber and Krushell in 1991 for detecting isolated rupture of the subscapularis tendon.

Procedure

  • The patient, while seated or standing, places the dorsum of the hand on their lower back (midlumbar region).
  • The arm is positioned in internal rotation.
  • The patient is asked to lift the dorsum of the hand off the back.

Positive Test

  • If the patient is unable to lift the hand off the back, the test is considered positive, indicating a possible subscapularis tendon rupture.

Confirmation

  • Electromyography shows that the subscapularis muscle is maximally active when the hand is in this position, particularly when resistance is applied.

Option A: Belly press test is another test for subscapularis. It also helps to compare the power of muscle with the opposite normal side.

Option B: Bear hug test is another test for subscapularis where the strength of muscle is tested against resistence.

Option D: Empty can test is used for supraspinatus muscle and sub-acromial impingement.


Fig. Empty can test for Supraspinatus


Fig. Subscapularis physical examination maneuvers. (A) Lift-off test. (B) Bellypress test. (C) Bear hug test.

Reference: Campbell's Operative Orthopaedics 14th edition page number: 2381

questions.text: An actor hit a wall while rehearsing a scene and sustained injury in his right hand. His xray is as follows. Identify the injury.
questions.solution:
Xray shown is of Boxer's fracture which usually occurs while punching with a closed fist.

Boxers' fracture: It is a ventrally displaced fracture through the neck of the 5th metacarpal, usually occurs in boxers.

Metacarpal Neck Fracture

Key Points

  • Weakest portion of the metacarpal.
  • Commonly affects the ring and small fingers.
  • Boxer's Fracture: Specifically the small finger.

Mechanism of Injury

  • Apex dorsal angulation due to intrinsic muscle forces.

Clinical Examination

  • Check for:
    • Malrotation
    • Pseudoclawing
    • MCP joint extensor lag

Treatment

  • Nonoperative:
    • Closed reduction (dorsal pressure/Jahss maneuver).
    • 3-4 weeks of immobilization.

Acceptable Angulation

  • Index/Long: <15-20 degrees
  • Ring: <30-40 degrees
  • Small: <60-70 degrees (controversial)

Considerations

  • Greater compensation from mobile fourth and fifth CMC joints.

Irreducible Fractures

  • Require CRPP (antegrade, retrograde, or transverse).

Option A: Bennett's fracture-dislocation: It is an oblique, intraarticular fracture of the base of the first metacarpal with subluxation of the trapezio-metacarpal joint.


Option B: Rolando fracture: Comminuted fracture of the base of the first metacarpal.


Option C: Mallet finger: A finger flexed at the DIP joint due to avulsion or rupture of extensor tendon at the base of the distal phalanx. Bony mallet finger has a bony chip avulsed from the insertion of extensor tendon.


Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 3.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page number: 1444

questions.text:
A 53 year old male with chronic lower back pain radiating to both lower limb consulted an orthopedic surgeon. Xray was as given below. Diagnose the condition. (Multiple correct answer)

1. Spondylosis
2. Spondilitis
3. Spondylolisthesis
4. Spondylolysis
questions.solution:
Pathology of Spondylolisthesis

Mechanism of Injury

  • Forward displacement of a vertebral body is normally prevented by:
    • Engagement of articular processes with the vertebra below.
    • Attachments of intervertebral discs and ligaments (minor role).
  • Defects in this mechanism lead to spondylolisthesis.

Types of Spondylolisthesis

  1. Isthmic(Most common)
    • Lesion in the pars interarticularis.
    • Subtypes:
      • Lytic: Fatigue fracture of the pars interarticularis.
      • Intact but elongated: Pars interarticularis is elongated.
      • Acute fracture: Fracture of the pars interarticularis.
    • The anterior half of the vertebra slips forward, while the posterior half remains with the lower vertebra.
  2. Dysplastic(Least common)
    • Congenital abnormality in vertebrae development leading to one vertebra slipping over another.
  3. Degenerative
    • Common in the elderly; instability of posterior facet joints due to osteoarthritis.
    • May result in backward displacement (retrolisthesis), usually mild with rare neurological disturbances.
  4. Pathological
    • Caused by generalized or localized bone disease weakening the articulation between vertebrae.
  5. Traumatic(Very rare)
    • Occurs following an injury, resulting in one vertebra slipping over another.

Fig. Scotty dog terrier sign in spondylolisthesis

Option C and D: Spondylolisthesis occurs as a result of spondylolysis.

Option A: Spondylosis: Degenerative spine disease commonly seen in old age.

Option B: Spondylitis : inflammatory condition involving the spine e.g. ankylosing spondylitis

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 283

questions.text: Identify the condition in which this type of gait is seen.
questions.solution:
Normally to transit weight of body during midstance phase of walking, the knee is locked with the help of quadriceps and popliteus muscles. If these are weak e.g. polio, locking will not occur and the knee will start buckling.

Therefore to stabilise the knee while walking, polio patients press their lower thigh backwards in order to lock the knee which in turn provides stability.

Option B: This type of gait is often called 'hand to knee gait' which is seen typically in poliomyelitis.

Option D: Foot drop - High steppage gait

Option A: CP - Scissoring gait

Option C: Gluteus medius weakness - Trendelenburgh gait

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 226, 370

questions.text: All of the following are possible treatment options of the fracture given below except:
questions.solution:
Treatment for Patella Fractures

The treatment for fractures depends on the type of fracture and, in some cases, the age of the patient. The following groups may be considered:

A) Undisplaced Fracture

  • Objective: Relief of pain.
  • Treatment:
    • A plaster cast extending from the groin to just above the malleoli, with the knee in full extension (cylinder cast).
    • Duration: 3 weeks, followed by physiotherapy.

B) Clean Break with Separation of Fragments (Two-Part Fracture)

  • Objective:Realignment of fragments.
  • Treatment:
    • An operation is necessary due to the pull of the quadriceps muscle on the proximal fragment.
    • Procedure includes:
      • Reduction of the fragments.
      • Fixing them with tension-band wiring (TBW).
      • Repair of extensor retinaculae.
    • The knee can be mobilized early following the operation.
  • Alternative Options:
    • If accurate reduction of fragments is not possible, excision of the fragments (patellectomy) may be performed, followed by repair of the extensor retinaculae.
    • If one fragment constitutes only one pole of the patella, it is excised while preserving the major fragment, with repair of the extensor retinaculae (partial patellectomy).
  • Post-Operative Care: Support in a cylinder cast for 4-6 weeks.

C) Comminuted Fracture

  • Objective: Address displacement and restore joint functionality.
  • Treatment:
    • For comminuted fractures with displacement, excision of the patella (patellectomy) is preferred to mitigate future risks of osteoarthritis at the patellofemoral joint.
    • With improvements in fixation techniques, more comminuted fractures of the patella are being reconstructed through patella-saving operations.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 147.

questions.text: A patient presented with prominence of medial border of scapula on pushing a wall. What is the diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Long Thoracic Nerve Palsy

  • Overview: Injury to the long thoracic nerve can lead to medial scapular winging, which is a result of dysfunction in the serratus anterior muscle
  • Causes:
    • Compression Injury: Commonly seen in backpackers.
    • Iatrogenic Injury: May occur following lymph node dissection for breast cancer.
    • Traction Injury: Often observed in weightlifters.
  • Management:
    • Observation: Many of these injuries tend to resolve spontaneously within 18 months, so simple observation is usually recommended.
    • Bracing: Treatment with a modified thoracolumbar brace may provide some benefit.
    • Surgery: In rare cases, pectoralis major transfer may be necessary for chronic palsies that do not show improvement.

Option B: Suprascapular nerve insufficiency will result in inability to abduct and external rotate the arm and not winging of scapula.

Option C: Sprengel shoulder / Congenitally High Scapula: Arrest of caudal migration of scapula from 9th to 12th week of gestation. Scapular stabilisers may be absent, hypoplastic and/or completely replaced by fibrous tissue. Associated with scoliosis, chest wall asymmetry and Kleippel Feil Syndrome.

Option D: Malunited scapula will be associated with history of high energy trauma and swelling and ecchymosis along the scapular region treated conservatively.

Reference: Miler's 8th Edition of Review of Orthopaedics, page number: 860.

questions.text: A pediatrician referred a 4 year old malnourished girl with following xray. Probable diagnosis?
questions.solution:
Radiological Features of Rickets

Early radiological changes are typically observed in the lower ends of the radius and ulna. For screening patients suspected of rickets, X-rays of both wrists and knees are performed in antero-posterior views. The following radiological signs may be seen:

  • Delayed Appearance of Epiphyses:
    • The epiphyses appear later than normal.
  • Widening of the Epiphyseal Plates:
    • The normal width of the epiphyseal plate is 2-4 mm. In rickets, this width is increased due to the excessive accumulation of uncalcified osteoid at the growth plate.
  • Cupping of the Metaphysis:
    • Normally, the metaphysis meets the epiphyseal plate with a smooth line of sclerosis (zone of provisional calcification). In rachitic bones, this line is absent, and the metaphyseal end appears irregular.
  • Splaying of the Metaphysis:
    • The end of the metaphysis is splayed due to pressure from cartilage cells accumulating at the growth plate.
  • Rarefaction of the Diaphysial Cortex:
    • This occurs later in the progression of the condition.
  • Bone Deformities:
    • Common deformities in older children include knock knees, bow legs, and coxa vara.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 311.

questions.text: A 33 year male had complains of pain and swelling in his left wrist. His xray is given below and his HPE on biopsy shows numerous gaint cells. Identify the lesion.
questions.solution:
The x-ray image shows classical soap bubble appearance seen in GCT (Osteoclastoma).

Giant Cell Tumor (GCT) of Bone

Overview: GCT is a common cause of solitary lytic bone lesions and should be differentiated from other lesions.

Radiological Features:

  • Lesion Type: Solitary, potentially loculated lytic lesion.
  • Location: Eccentric, epiphyseal (subchondral).
  • Cortex Expansion: Expansile lesion with a 'soap-bubble' appearance due to trabecular remnants.
  • Calcification: No calcification within the tumor.
  • Reactive Sclerosis: None or minimal around the tumor.
  • Cortex Integrity: Thinned or perforated cortex.
  • Joint Involvement: Usually does not invade adjacent joints.

Pathology:

  • Cell of Origin: Uncertain.
  • Microscopic Features: Composed of undifferentiated spindle cells and multinucleate giant cells in a highly vascular stroma.
  • Terminology: Giant cells were previously mistaken for osteoclasts, hence the name osteoclastoma.

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 237.

questions.text: A 14 year old girl presents with progressive swelling and pain in lower thigh for 2 months. There is no recalled history of trauma or any signs of infection. Her MRI shows possibility of osteosarcoma. All of these will be seen in her x-ray except:
questions.solution:
Option C: Fallen leaf sign is found in unicameral bone cyst (UBC)

Investigations for Osteosarcoma Diagnosis

The following investigations may be conducted to confirm the diagnosis:

  1. Radiological Examination:
  • X-ray Findings:
    • Irregular Destruction (Option B): Area of irregular destruction in the metaphysis, sometimes overshadowed by new bone formation; the cortex over the lesion is eroded.
    • Periosteal Reaction: Intense periosteal reaction as the tumor lifts the periosteum; this reaction is irregular in osteosarcoma (unlike the smooth, layered reaction in osteomyelitis).
    • Codman's Triangle (Option D): Triangular area of subperiosteal new bone at the tumor-host cortex junction.
    • Sun-Ray Appearance (Option A): Tumor growth into overlying soft tissues results in new bone laid down along blood vessels, creating a 'sun-ray appearance' on X-ray.
  1. Serum Alkaline Phosphatase (SAP):
  • Generally elevated but of no diagnostic significance.
  • Considered useful for monitoring osteosarcoma; a rise after initial fall post-tumor removal may indicate recurrence or metastasis.
  1. Biopsy:
  • An open biopsy is performed for diagnosis confirmation.
  • Some pathologists can diagnose osteosarcoma from small tissue samples obtained via core biopsy or fine needle aspiration cytology (FNAC).

Reference: J. Maheshwari's 5th Edition of Essential Orthopaedics page number: 240, 251.
